he Duke OF York continued sick and all hopes

FROM PORTUGAL


Up to the 3lst OF December, the British Capital
had bte l9 days without any direct intelligence
from Portugal. In the mean time the FleEth pa.
pers were filled with the most idle and ridiculous
stories. One of these ha, the rebels had taken
Opor,o. These stores however, were dissipated
by The arrival Of .he vessel Sir Edward Ra rks
on the night of Dec. lst, with despstehe. from
Lisbon, whence the messenger sailed on the 26 h of
December. Ii does not appear that any eveIis Of
importance occurred in Portugal subsequtn nj to The
capture of Braganza The measures adopted by the
BRUSH government had d,fiused the greatest Joy az
that place. The squadron, with troops from Eng.
land, had Just arrived off the hsrbor. One vessel
had previously arrived and landed her troops, who
were received with he greatest acclamatlons.

Washington, February We said, in our last
mat the Bankrupt Bill was defeated: and so il was
N the universal opinion, as we'll in our belief by
he solemn vote OF rejection, in the Senate BY The
process OF reconsideration Of that vote however the
b has been resusclt.ted perhaps only to brief ex
is'enoe, but possibly 10 different destiny. 1t was
reeonsdered yesterday, with the avowed purpose
which will be probably carried into effect Of s,rik'
ing out the 93d section, which authorizes Others
than raiders. with their consent, but not other
wise to become bankrupts under the provisions Of
the law This provision was inserted, to conciliate
the favor oi the agricultural and other interests not
Included 10 The bankupt system it exists IN other
countries. Wihou, having this effect to any i'm
portan extent, however, the~inse ton oi that pro
vision determined several votes a. anst the bill, which
would otherwise ave been in favor o t--a sufficien
nun Der II 70 supposed, to have decided the fate o
the bill as 1t was actually de ermiped by the vote
ot w ednesday. The question now presented, is,
whether the 93d section shall be expunged and, If
It be expuoged. whether the bill shall pass as
system OF bankrupty adapted to merchants and
traders only. II is supposed that both these ques
tions will be decided TO day, 10 the Senate though
possibly not soon.


he whole country looks with great interest, to
the lesult OF this great question; II being mo ally
certain, that, ii it fail now il fail, for the present
generation. II is not considered Of SO much conse
quence. however great the consequence may he.

should * put 6na 10 ,tst. Intel

VERY LATE FROM ENGLAND.

IL


VERY LATE FROM ENGLAND


The pscse ships Canada, Rogers, aud Leeds,
Stoddard arrived las evening from Liverpool, both
We sells haeing sailed The Sd OF January, 10 which
dates inclusive. the Editors OF the Commercial Ad !.
ver,iser have received files OF papers, with regu.
ar file OF Lloyds Lists to the 30th Of December.


The Ne" York packet shii Canada, Captain Ro-
gers, was seized by The Officers of the Customs at
Liverpool. in consequence OF the discovery. on Dec.
l5,h. that ten hogshtads, purpofing TO be filed
with qoercron bark, which had been landed |, ON
that vessel, contained quantity Of tobacco and
snuff Jeremiah Plat. the consienee of the hogs
heads in question, was taken into custody or the
4,h Dec and Detained under special clause IN
the Act OF parliar ent, % in order 10 give time for
preparing the Information against him" The case
having, in the mean time, been reported to the Board
o! Customs in London, OF ders were sent down to
proceed against the defendant upon an info, nation
toi 'Ged fom the Custom house in London. Ac-
cordingy. on Friday, MIR Plat was placed at the
bar in the town hail. and the information char ging
him with Illegally unshipping and landing, or caus-
ing to be unshipped, being proved against him. he
sas fired 100 pounds.


The Creek frigs,e He las, from New York, had
arrived of Malta-al well She proceeded imme-
distriy,' Nspoli.


The North Carolina, Com. Rogers, anchored 10
the Roadsled oi Coulon. on the lOth Dec.


he Duke OF York continued sick and all hopes
Of his recovery were despaired Of. His compsint
is Dropsy in the Chest. He is doubtless dead be.
lore now and the Duke Of Ciarence, "a Radical) is
IN that case the heir apparent. The Duke oi Cia-
renee has an abundance OF children but nope legiii.
mate. The mex in succession is the infant daugh.
ter Of The late Duke OF Kent. In the event Of the
loss o this heess pre.ump,ive, the crown would
deyolve upon the Duke ot Cumberland, who has lie.
gitimate offspring. Next to the Duke Of Cumber.
Nab. u l.
last of the late kings SONS, is the Duke OF Cam
bridge.


William Clifford Esq EDITOR Of the Quarterly
Review died in London, on the 3lst o! December,
N he 7lst year Of his a.e.


AS We anticipated, the news from The Continent
is decidedly pacific. The prompt and decided mea&
oil the British cabinet. as regards the iDva.
sion OF Portugal. had The desired effect and The
peace Of Europe will no be di,tui bea.


FROM SPAN.


The Courier Francais De- smher 26, says.
+" Authentic accounts irou Madrid STATE, that King
Ferdinaod, in consequence OF the ultimatum " hch
has been presented 10 him. requring him TO ausw er
it without Gelav and without subettuge has lust zee
cognised The Consti ulions Government and Char.
ter oi Pottoga!, has p om ed to send An bssadof
to Lisbon, and to receive one from The Regency to
break off all kind o. commotions and completely
with the Portuguese reb.lilon snd to give all Other





him by Euglsnd,''


This Intelligence is confirmed by all the other
French papers.


FROM PORTUGAL


Up to the 3lst OF December, the British Capital
had bte l9 days without any direct intelligence
from Portugal. In the mean time the FleEth pa.
pers were filled with the most idle and ridiculous
stories. One of these ha, the rebels had taken
Opor,o. These stores however, were dissipated
by The arrival Of .he vessel Sir Edward Ra rks
on the night of Dec. lst, with despstehe. from
Lisbon, whence the messenger sailed on the 26 h of
December. Ii does not appear that any eveIis Of
importance occurred in Portugal subsequtn nj to The
capture of Braganza The measures adopted by the
BRUSH government had d,fiused the greatest Joy az
that place. The squadron, with troops from Eng.
land, had Just arrived off the hsrbor. One vessel
had previously arrived and landed her troops, who
were received with he greatest acclamatlons.


THE GREEKS

sotiations at Censsnlinople, between the Foreign

roops which we're already Oh board ~ exsndris,

ants taking ad, antage Of The absence of sny American
and openly violating the laws Of their country

We have here occasion to regret the failure oI the
caton fora muaa right Of search, which would most pro-
badly, in this instance. have enabled our cruzers who

from the coast"


I his paragraph is recommended to the Editor OF
the Genius OF Universal Emancipation, Baltimore
and he is desired 10 inquire how it is pos lble hst
vessels can be fitted out IN The poi, OF Baltimore
(where there are SO many persons opposed to trsi.
fc that dsgt that city that has become the head
quarters of abolilior,) without the matt, getting to
The knowledge oi the proper authorities for the sup
preston Of such acts. But a, the time that
write this, am aware OF The possibility of carrying
traffic contrary TO law, and contrary TO the prin
cples OF humanity and the opinions OF the mass OF
the community among which ii is effected-from
Circumstance that has recently come to my know
ledge.


There is uithin a fer miles Of philadelphia,
(not more than sir ar Seren o person who, pos.
sessng farm on that spot, and one in Mary land
where he keeps number OF slaves is in the prac-
tict Of transporting his said slaves from Maryland
to Pennsylvania TO work his farm there Here
he suffers them to remain for near The siT months.
that the Pennsylvania law permits them 10 continue
when he returns them to Mary yland-and in con
sequence OF this arrangement passes them tuice in
IL months through the State Of Delaware, (i, is pre-
sumed) contrary to our law -as it is species Of
Internal traffic IN stares-contrary no doubt TO the
principles That obtain b'th in Pennsylvanis and al
least that part oi the state OF Delaware through
which those slaves probably transported. 1t is
true that they may be transported by water from
the shores OF Delaware TO the neghhorhood ni
Chester--but in any way it is presumed that they
pass through apart Uf this State.
